back: Heredity; the genetic transmission of characteristics from parents to their offspring.
Environment; the sum of all external conditions affecting development, including especially the effects of learning.
Agents that cause malformation of an embryo. For example, alcohol, drugs, and viruses.
Involuntary responses to stimuli. For example, the rooting reflex, sucking reflex, grasping reflex, and Moro reflex.
A reflex that causes a newborn to turn its head toward the source of touching that occurs anywhere around its mouth.
A reflex that causes a newborn to suck at anything that touches the area around its mouth.
A reflex that causes a newborn to grasp anything that touches the palm of its hand or the sole of its foot.

A reflex that causes a newborn to startle in response to a loud noise or sudden movement in which the fling out their arms and legs and then retract them in order to make themselves as small as possible.
A reflex that causes a newborn to spread its toes when the sole of its foot is stroked.
A laboratory device for testing depth perception in infants and young animals.
The ability to move the body and manipulate objects. For example, fine motor skills and gross motor skills.
The ability to control large muscle movements. For example, crawling, walking, and running.
The organized set of beliefs and expectations that guides oneâ€™s understanding of gender.
Development that occurs in distinct stages, with each stage bringing about behavior that is assumed to be qualitatively different from behavior at earlier stages.
A rapid increase in height and weight that occurs during puberty.
The difference between what a learner can do without help and what he or she can do with help.
Erik Erikson's theory that individuals pass through eight developmental stages, each with a crisis that must be resolved.
The first psychosocial stage, in which infants learn to trust when they are cared for in a consistent warm manner.
The second psychosocial stage, in which toddlers learn to exercise will and do things independently; failure to do so causes shame and doubt.
The third psychosocial stage, in which the child finds independence in planning, playing and other activities.
The fourth psychosocial stage, in which the child learns to be productive.
The fifth psychosocial stage, in which teenagers and young adults search for and become their true selves.
The sixth psychosocial stage, in which individuals form deeply personal relationships, marry, begin families.
The seventh psychosocial stage, in which middle-aged people begin to devote themselves more to fulfilling one's potential and doing public service.
The eighth psychosocial stage, in which those near the end of life look back and evaluate their lives.
The belief that others are as preoccupied with the adolescent as they are themselves.
The process of taking in new information into our already existing schemas. For example, a child sees a zebra and calls it a horse. This process does not change the schema.

The process of altering or adjusting old schemas to fit new information and experiences. For example, a child sees a zebra and calls it a horse. The parent corrects the child and says it is a zebra. This process changes the schema.

Mental structures that organize our knowledge and assumptions about something and are used for interpreting and processing information. For instance, a child has a schema for a horse and sees a zebra. The child calls the zebra a horse.
A concept that objects continue to exist even when they cannot be seen. For example, a child will look for a toy that has been hidden under a blanket.
The ability to use symbols to represent objects, actions, and ideas. For example, a child can use a block to represent a car.
A concept in which a child is unable to see a situation from another person's point of view. For example, a child may think that everyone sees the world as they do.
Also referred to as fantasy play, it is a type of play in which children use their imagination to create scenarios and roles. For example, a child may pretend to be a doctor or a teacher.
The understanding that others have thoughts, beliefs, and perspectives that are different from one's own. For example, a child may understand that their friend is sad because they lost a toy.

The understanding that certain properties of objects remain the same despite changes in their form or appearance. For example, a child may understand that a tall, thin glass holds the same amount of liquid as a short, wide glass.

The stage of cognitive development (12 years and up) during which people begin to think logically about abstract concepts. For example, a child can solve algebraic equations and understand hypothetical situations.
The ability to think about concepts and ideas that are not physically present or concrete. For example, a child can understand the concept of justice or freedom.
The ability to think about possibilities and hypothetical situations. For example, a child can understand the consequences of a decision before making it.

The stage of cognitive development (7 to 11 years) during which children gain a better understanding of mental operations. For example, a child can understand the concept of conservation and can classify objects into categories.
The awareness and understanding of one's own thought processes. For example, a child may reflect on their own learning strategies and adjust them accordingly.
The belief that one's experiences and feelings are unique and not understood by others. For example, a teenager may believe that no one else has ever felt the same way they do.
The smallest units of sound in a language that can distinguish one word from another. For example, the sounds /b/ and /p/ in the words 'bat' and 'pat'.
The smallest units of meaning in a language. For example, the word 'cats' has two morphemes: 'cat' (the animal) and 's' (indicating plural).
The set of rules that govern the structure of sentences in a language. For example, in English, the typical word order is subject-verb-object (SVO).
The study of meaning in language. For example, the word 'dog' refers to a specific type of animal.
The stage of language development in which infants produce repetitive consonant-vowel combinations, such as 'ba-ba' or 'da-da.' This stage typically occurs around 4 to 6 months of age.

The stage of language development in which infants use single words to convey whole ideas or sentences. For example, a child may say 'milk' to mean 'I want milk.' This stage typically occurs around 12 months of age.

The stage of language development in which children use single words to express complete thoughts. For example, a child may say 'up' to mean 'pick me up.' This stage typically occurs around 12 months of age.

The stage of language development in which children use two or three-word phrases that contain only the essential words needed to convey meaning. For example, a child may say 'want cookie' instead of 'I want a cookie.' This stage typically occurs around 18 to 24 months of age.

The stage of language development in which children use two-word combinations to express simple ideas. For example, a child may say 'big truck' to describe a large vehicle. This stage typically occurs around 18 to 24 months of age.

The application of a grammatical rule too widely and thereby creating incorrect forms. For example, a child may say 'goed' instead of 'went' or 'mouses' instead of 'mice.' This stage typically occurs around 2 to 3 years of age.

The application of regular grammatical rules to irregular nouns and verbs. For example, a child may say 'runned' instead of 'ran' or 'foots' instead of 'feet.' This stage typically occurs around 2 to 3 years of age.

A specific time during development when an organism is particularly sensitive to certain environmental stimuli. For example, the critical period for language acquisition is thought to be during early childhood.
A parenting style that emphasizes close physical and emotional bonds between parent and child, often involving practices such as co-sleeping and extended breastfeeding.
A person's characteristic emotional reactivity and intensity. For example, a child may be described as easy, difficult, or slow to warm up.

A strong emotional bond between a child and caregiver, characterized by trust and a sense of safety. For example, a securely attached child will feel comfortable exploring their environment while knowing they can return to their caregiver for support.

A type of insecure attachment characterized by a lack of emotional connection and avoidance of closeness with caregivers. For example, an avoidant child may not seek comfort from their caregiver when upset.
A type of insecure attachment characterized by anxiety and uncertainty in relationships. For example, an anxious/ambivalent child may cling to their caregiver but also resist comfort when offered.

A type of insecure attachment characterized by ambivalence and resistance to comfort from caregivers. For example, a resistant child may cry when their caregiver leaves but also push them away when they return.
A type of attachment characterized by anxiety and uncertainty in relationships. For example, an insecurely attached child may have difficulty forming healthy relationships in adulthood.
The distress that a child experiences when separated from their primary caregiver. For example, a child may cry or become upset when their parent leaves the room.
The immediate environment in which a person lives, including family, friends, and school. For example, a child's microsystem includes their home, school, and neighborhood.
The interconnections between the various microsystems in a person's life. For example, the relationship between a child's home and school environments.
The larger social system in which a person lives, including community, government, and media. For example, a child's exosystem includes their neighborhood, school district, and local government.
The broader cultural context in which a person lives, including societal values, customs, and laws. For example, a child's macrosystem includes the cultural norms and values of their society.

The dimension of time in relation to a person's development, including life transitions and historical events. For example, a child's chronosystem includes the timing of significant life events, such as moving to a new city or experiencing a natural disaster.
Parents who are demanding and unresponsive. They impose rules and expect obedience, but do not provide warmth or emotional support.
Parents who are warm and responsive but do not impose rules or expectations. They allow children to make their own decisions and set their own limits.
Parents who are both demanding and responsive. They set high expectations for their children but also provide warmth and support.
